Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Topology Design in Socio-Temporal Evolving Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Wireless networks often evolve over time: changes of topology can occur if some nodes appear, disappear, or move around. Such dynamics over time domain are often ignored in protocol design or simply modeled by pure randomness such as in the well-known random walk mobility model. However, in real wireless networks, the node mobility and topology evolution depend heavily on both social and temporal characteristics of the network and network participants. In such socio-temporal evolving wireless networks, traditional communication protocols designed for mobile ad hoc networks and delay tolerant networks are inefficient due to time-varying structures, long delays, and the lack of continuous connectivity. To address this problems, this project seeks a new exploratory study of socio-temporal evolving wireless networks and topology control protocols for such networks, specifically, to (1) analyze and model socio-temporal dynamics of evolving wireless networks by using real-life wireless networking tracing data; (2) design efficient topology control protocols based on these socio-temporal models. The expected results include new socio-temporal models and novel topology control protocols, which can support many new civilian and military applications. The success of this project provides a deep understanding of both social and temporal properties of time-evolving wireless networks and enhances the interdisciplinary research between network science and social science. The research results will be incorporated into networking courses and widely disseminated through conference/journal publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past several years, topology control of large-scale wireless networks has drawn a significant amount of research interests. Primary topology control algorithms aim to maintain network connectivity, optimize network throughput, and conserve energy. These topology control protocols deal with topology changes by re-performing the construction algorithms. However, all of these methods assume that the underlying network is fully connected and the time domain knowledge of network evolution is neglected. In real world, networks often evolve over time: changes of topology can occur if some nodes appear, disappear, or move around. The node mobility and topology evolution depend heavily on both social and temporal characteristics of the network and network participants. To date, little work has been dedicated to exploring topology design and social analysis for time-evolving networks. In contrast with traditional topology design methods, this EAGER project adopts new model to analyze socio-temporal dynamics, designs radically different approaches for topology design, and engages novel interdisciplinary perspectives from social networks, real-life wireless data, and networking science.

To model the time-evolving networks, different space-time graph models are introduced. Several topology design problems has been formally defined and showed to be computationally challenging to obtain the optimal solutions. New efficient topology control algorithms are designed to address various topology requirements in time-evolving wireless networks. Via extensive simulations over both random networks and real-life wireless tracing data (including several large scale cellular user datasets), the new proposed methods are evaluated and proved to be efficient and effective.

In addition, several new social metrics (such as social energy and multi-level social groups) and corresponding social-based routing protocols are proposed to take advantage of social properties discovered from mining these mobile tracing data. The experimental results show that considering wide range of social properties of mobile users can indeed improve the delivery ratio of routing protocols especially when the network is not always connected. Combining different social information (such as centrality or location profile or social groups) may further benefit the social-based approaches.

The exploration of these new approaches and theoretical analysis reveals key insights that enable the performance optimization in large-scale mobile networks with better understanding of social and temporal characteristics of the network and network participants. The results from this project hopefully provide us a set of new knowledge of social dynamics among mobile users and a new way to the integration of social network analysis, topology design, and routing techniques in mobile networks. In addition, the results also provide new fundamental theories and advanced technologies for the design of future large-scale wireless and mobile networks. Thus, they have great potentials to inspire new commercialized future wireless and mobile systems and applications which will have broad societal impact on people’s daily life.
